Award.AwardTitle: Quantifying the Genome-wide Influence of Human Selection on Leaf Morphology and Amino Acid Metabolism in Cole Crops
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds an NSF National Plant Genome Initiative Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2017. The fellowship supports a research and training plan in a host laboratory for the Fellow who also presents a plan to broaden participation in biology. The host institution for the fellowship is the University of Missouri and the sponsoring scientists are Drs. Timothy Beissinger, J. Chris Pires, and Ruthie Angelovici.

Domesticated cruciferous vegetables in Brassica oleracea, commonly known as cole crops, were selected from wild mustard to encompass a wide range of morphological and nutritional attributes. Despite extreme physical differences among cultivars, little is known about the extent of genetic diversity and developmental trade-offs in cole crops. Of interest is how selection for larger vegetative organs has influenced amino acid metabolism, which is important in leaves for human nutritional quality and for seed germinability to ensure continued evolution and improvement. This project uses a multi-disciplinary approach to address fundamental questions regarding how domestication has influenced genetic diversity and amino acid metabolism in a diversity panel of B. oleracea. Training objectives include quantitative genetics, population genetics, bioinformatics, and metabolomics. Broader impacts include mentoring of students, guest lecturing, and outreach events exploring the connections between food systems and crop domestication.

There is need to expand domestication research beyond the cereals to additional crops with global and nutritional importance. In this project, the fellow will study domestication and demographic history in B. oleracea by testing for genomic signatures of selection, characterizing previous bottlenecks and expansions, studying trade-offs in amino acid metabolism between leaves and seeds, and identifying genomic regions of interest for these traits. This will include the resequencing of a diversity panel of B. oleracea, network analysis of amino acid composition in leaves and seeds, quantitative assessment of leaf morphology, and identification of the structural variation contributing to the observed phenotypes. All data, scripts, and methodologies produced from this work will be deposited in open-access repositories.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding the evolutionary history and impact of domestication of crops is critical for continued improvement and breeding efforts. During the domestication process, crop species typically experience a population bottleneck, or a reduction in genetic diversity, compared to their wild relatives. This reduction in allelic diversity is often observed in genomic regions that contribute to agricultural performance; for example, many grain crops were selected to prevent seed shattering. Expanding our knowledge of how the domestication process has influenced genetic diversity in crops helps identify opportunities to reintroduce trait variation (e.g. to improve disease/pest resistance) and to understand which breeding strategies will be most effective for crop improvement. The goals of this research were to apply population genetic methods to study the impact of domestication on Brassica oleracea, a crop species which includes familiar vegetables like kale, cabbage, kohlrabi, broccoli, cauliflower, and Brussels sprouts, and to relate population genetic principles to applied plant breeding.

 

Given the striking variation of crop types present within a single species, Brassica oleracea is both a popular and intriguing example of crop domestication. To better understand how the domestication process has affected diversity in these different crop types, I generated whole genome sequence data for a diverse panel of Brassica oleracea and its wild relatives. This genomic resource enabled me to estimate the demographic history, genetic diversity, and relatedness among wild relatives and domesticated crop types. In addition to genetic data, this project also involved the collection of trait data for hypothesized domestication traits, which included leaf area and glucosinolates (compounds that impart the pungent flavor of these crops and contribute to plant defense against pests). Both the genetic and trait data collected for this project will provide a valuable resource for future population genetic and quantitative genetic studies.

 

One of the ultimate goals of population and quantitative genetics is to connect genetic data to trait variation. A powerful tool to accomplish this goal in plant and animal breeding is genomic prediction, which seeks to estimate an individual’s breeding value, or expected contribution to trait values in offspring, based solely on genetic data. As part of this project, I leveraged public data for Arabidopsis thaliana, a model species in the same family as Brassica oleracea, to test how prior knowledge of biological pathways can be used in genomic prediction models to understand trait variation. Using this approach, I found evidence that genetic variation in specific biological pathways significantly influenced trait variation for free amino acid content in seeds, which is an important component of plant and animal nutrition.

 

Over the duration of this project, I developed publicly available, reproducible bioinformatic pipelines and data resources, which can be used to support additional studies in Brassica oleracea or other species. Additionally, I trained undergraduate and graduate students on the use of bioinformatic tools and computational image analysis. Findings from this work contribute to the broader body of knowledge surrounding crop domestication and improvement.
